title: PCT 31: A buffalo in human form
author: Coming-Day

sentences.original: pêyak nikîh-wâpamâw kisêyiniw; êyôkô ê-kîh-âcimot kisêyiniw ômis îtwêw, nik-âcimon, itwêw.
sentences.text: pêyak nikî-wâpamâw kisêyiniw êwako ê-kî-âcimot kisêyiniw ômisi itwêw itwêw
sentences.english: A certain old man whom I am old enough to have known, used to tell this story. “I shall tell of what I have seen,” he would say.

sentences.original: kîtahtawê pêyak nâpêw wî-sipwêhtêw, ê-wih-ntonawât ayahciyiniwah.
sentences.text: kîtahtawê pêyak nâpêw wî-sipwêhtêw ê-wî-nitonawât ayahciyiniwa
sentences.english: At one time a certain man was going to set out to look for Blackfoot.
He told me of his purpose (said this old man).
So he set out.
I went along;
eight was the number of us young men who went on the war-path.

sentences.original: kîtahtawê êh-pa-pimohtêyâhk, êkwah wâhyaw êh-ayâyâhk, kîtahtawê êh-apiyâhk, êh-pîhtwâyâhk, pêyak oskinîkiw ê-sipwêhtêt, ê-wî-sâkêwêt ispatinâhk, ê-wîh-kakwê-wâpamât ayihciyiniwah, êh-ntawâhtât awa kâ-wiy-nanâtawâpit ispatinâhk ohci, êh-itâpit, wâpamêw mostoswah nêwo.
sentences.text: kîtahtawê ê-pa-pimohtêyâhk êkwa wâhyaw ê-ayâyâhk kîtahtawê ê-apiyâhk ê-pîhtwâyâhk pêyak oskinîkiw ê-sipwêhtêt ê-wî-sâkêwêt ispatinâhk ê-wî-kakwê-wâpamât ayahciyiniwa ê-nitawâhtât awa kâ-wî-nanâtawâpit ispatinâhk ohci ê-itâpit wâpamêw mostoswa nêwo
sentences.english: Presently as we marched along, after we had gone a great distance, then once, as we sat smoking, a young man left camp to reach the crest of a hill, to look out for Blackfoot, and when this scout reconnoitred, as he looked yon way, he saw four buffalo.
He signaled to his companions.
Accordingly they rose to their feet and went to where that young man was.
When they reached him, “How is it?” the leader asked him.
“Oh, merely that there are some buffalo here.”
“Very well, try to kill them,” said that old man.
A young man set out to shoot them.

sentences.original: êkwah êh-nâciyôstawât êh-apiyit, cîk êy-ihtât, kâ-wâpamât wâkayôsah êh-nâciyôstawâyit ôhi mostoswah.
sentences.text: êkwa ê-nâciyôstawât ê-apiyit cîki ê-ihtât kâ-wâpamât wâkayôsa ê-nâciyôstawâyit ôhi mostoswa
sentences.english: Then, when he crept up to them and was crouching now quite near, he saw a bear stealing up to these buffalo.

sentences.original: êkosi pê-kîwêw aw oskinîkiw, êh-kostât ôhi wâkayôsah, êh-âcimostawât owîcêwâkanah.
sentences.text: êkosi pê-kîwêw awa oskinîkiw ê-kostât ôhi wâkayôsa ê-âcimostawât owîcêwâkana
sentences.english: Thereupon the young man came back, afraid of the bear, and told his companions the story.

sentences.original: wâkayôs nâciyôstawêw ôhih mostoswah, itêw ôwîcêwâkanah.
sentences.english: “A bear is stealing up to these buffalo,” he told his com panions.

sentences.original: mahtih kitâpamâtân tânsih kê-tôtahk ôwo wâkayôs, êkosih itwêwak.
sentences.english: “Let us go see how this bear will do,” they said.
So they arose and seated themselves on a small eminence of the ground to watch the animals.

sentences.original: âsay cîkih ayâw wâkayôs ôhih takwâhnâwa.
sentences.text: âsay cîki ayâw wâkayôs ôhi takwahinâwa
sentences.english: By this time the bear had got close to the bull buffalos.

sentences.original: kîtahatawê pasikôw awah takwâhnaw pêyak, ê-at-sipwêhtêt, êh-itohtêt ôhi wâkayôsah.
sentences.text: kîtahtawê pasikôw awa takwahinâw pêyak ê-ati-sipwêhtêt ê-itohtêt ôhi wâkayôsa
sentences.english: Suddenly one bull arose, left the others, and went up to the bear.

sentences.original: pasikôw awa wâkayôs, êh-otihtikot ôhih takwâhnawah.
sentences.text: pasikôw awa wâkayôs ê-otihtikot ôhi takwahinâwa
sentences.english: When the bull came near, the bear also rose.
They fought.
Not long did they fight.
The bull was killed.

sentences.original: mayaw êh-nipahiht kotak pasikôw. mînah êyakô êh-itohtêt ôh îtah kâh-nipahimiht.
sentences.text: mayaw ê-nipahiht kotak pasikôw mîna êwako ê-itohtêt ôhi ita kâ-nipahimiht
sentences.english: As soon as it had been killed, another rose and went to where the first one had been killed.
This one, too, fought with the bear.
Soon it, also, was killed by the bear.

sentences.original: kotak mînah pasikôw, êh-itohtêt, ê-wîh-nôtinât wâkayôsah.
sentences.text: kotak mîna pasikôw ê-itohtêt ê-wî-nôtinât wâkayôsa
sentences.english: Then another still rose up and encountered the bear and fought with it.
They fought;
this one, too, the bear killed.
Then the remaining one rose up, angry.
It, too, went up to the bear.
It, too, fought; the bear killed it.
The bear killed all four of the bulls.

sentences.original: itah kâ-kîh-apicik ôkih takwâhnawak, êkotah ohci pasikôw osk-âyîsis.
sentences.text: ita kâ-kî-apicik ôki takwahinâwak êkota ohci pasikôw osk-âyîsis
sentences.english: Then from that place where those four bulls had been there arose a young buffalo.

sentences.original: êwako êkotah pâh-pimicipayiw, êh-kisiwâsit, êh-môskîstawât ôhi wâkayôsah.
sentences.text: êwako êkota pâh-pimicipayiw ê-kisiwâsit ê-môskîstawât ôhi wâkayôsa
sentences.english: It ran along angrily toward the bear, to attack it.
[no translation]
When it got up, it had the form of a man holding a lance.
The bear was afraid of this one.
When it tried to escape, the man attacked it.
He stabbed the bear and killed it.

sentences.original: êkosi êkwah kawipayihôw; êh-pasikôt, pôtiy êyakô mostosis.
sentences.text: êkosi êkwa kawipayihôw ê-pasikôt pôti êwako mostosis
sentences.english: Then he flung himself on the ground; when he arose, there was again that young buffalo.

sentences.original: êkosi tapasîw awa mostosis; tâpwê pikô nimitâw isi-tapasîw.
sentences.text: êkosi tapasîw awa mostosis tâpwê piko nimitaw isi-tapasîw
sentences.english: So the young buffalo ran away; it made for the open prairie.

sentences.original: êkosi êkwah ôki oskinîkiwak itohtêwak, êh-ntawâpamâcik ôhi mostoswah kâ-nipahimiht.
sentences.text: êkosi êkwa ôki oskinîkiwak itohtêwak ê-nitawâpamâcik ôhi mostoswa kâ-nipahimiht
sentences.english: Thereupon the young men went to the place to look at the buffalos that had been killed.

sentences.original: êh-takohtêcik, êh-wâ-wâpamâcik, kahkiyaw awa wâkayôs êh-kaskikwênât, êkwah awa wâkayôs ospiskwanihk nôkwaniyiw êkotah êh-tahkamikot ôhi mostosisah, tâpiskôc ayîsiyiniw ê-kîh-tahkamât.
sentences.text: ê-takohtêcik ê-wâ-wâpamâcik kahkiyaw awa wâkayôs ê-kaskikwênât êkwa awa wâkayôs ospiskwanihk nôkwaniyiw êkota ê-tahkamikot ôhi mostosisa tâpiskôc ayîsiyiniw ê-kî-tahkamât
sentences.english: When they got there and examined them, it appeared that the bear had broken the necks of them all, and in the bear's back they could see the place where the buffalo-calf had stabbed it, exactly as though a man had made the wound.
Then the young men skinned them and cut them up.
“We shall eat,” they said.
Accordingly they built fires to prepare parched meat and to eat.

sentences.original: êkwah awa kisêyiniw ômis îtwêw : oskinîkîtik, kayâs nôhcîn;
sentences.english: Then the old man spoke as follows: “Youths, I am an old man;
never have I seen anything like this.
Perhaps we shall not fare well;
perhaps the Blackfoot will slay us.
We had better go back.
It will be better if we go home,” said the old man.
“Very well,” said the young men.
They stayed there one night.
In the morning they set out for home.
At last they reached their camp.
They told their story.

sentences.original: êk ohci k-oh-pê-kîwêyâhk, êh-itêyihtamâhk, êh-isi-wâpahtamân, k-oh-pê-kîwêyân.
sentences.english: “That is why we have come home, 'Perhaps we shall not fare well,' was our thought, so it seemed to me; that is why I turned back.”
So much for this story.
Twin-Buffalo, he is the one who had this experience;
my mother's brother was this old man.
